title: Rental Sector and New High-End Homes Driving Development in London
text:
Residential real estate developers in London are continuing to build in the city despite the enduring political uncertainty clouding the market, according to a report released earlier this week from Knight Frank.



The number of new residential units given planning permission or consent in inner London reached 5,673 in the first quarter of the year, more than the total in inner London during the previous two quarters—led by a handful of large projects in Wandsworth and Tower Hamlets.

That number dropped down to 1,290 in the second quarter of 2019, “reflecting the prevailing uncertainty and challenging planning environment,” the estate agency and property consultants said.



Helping drive development is a lack of sites available to purchase, which has halted the decline in land values in central London; a strong demand for private rental developments; and resilience at the top end of central London’s new-build market, according to Knight Frank.



The market for purpose-built rental stock in London took off a decade ago, powered by “demographic changes and demand from investors from North America,” the report said.



There were 6,816 rental homes approved for construction in schemes comprising at least 100 units during the first six months of the year, an increase of more than 20% year-on-year.

Meanwhile sales of luxury new homes are proving resilient.



While sales of existing super-prime homes have slowed this year, new home sales have gained a greater market share, from a recent low of 18% in the second quarter of 2017 to 34% in the second quarter this year.



“Prime buyers are increasingly focused on securing a London residence in a new scheme and typically they prioritize a high level of security and extensive amenities,” said Rupert des Forges, head of prime central London developments at Knight Frank, in the report. “Prime apartments offer a seamless move away from transient hotel living for the new generation of global wealth now driving the top end of the London market.”
